Oughta see ’em reel and rock
A “reel” is a term for a lively dance. but “reel” can also mean to stumble around, like a drunkard. Chuck is combining these two meanings…
She’s got a crazy partner
It takes two crazy dancers to make a great team…
Dance like a spinning top
Dancing in a 50’s dress could make a girl look like a top…

As long as she got a dime
 The music will never stop
She’s going to keep putting dimes in the jukebox, to make sure the Rock and Roll keeps playing.
Hey diddle diddle

This line, and the one after it, are a reference to the nursury rhyme, “Hey diddle diddle, the cat and the fiddle”



Chuck makes himself “the cat”.
I’ll play my fiddle
and by “fiddle”, he means his guitar…
Roll over Beethoven

Chuck might be referring to Beethoven “rolling over in his grave” about the emergence of Rock and Roll music. However, Chuck doesn’t seem very concerned about how he might be annoying the great composer.
Well early in the morning

A song of the period.

Don’t you step on my blue suede shoes

The classic Carl Perkins tune, best known through Elvis Presley.

Roll over Beethoven
 Gotta hear it again today

The song was inspired by Chuck Berry’s sister Lucy always using the family piano to play classical music when Chuck wanted to play popular music. After all, the good old Ludwig Van doesn’t need to be played at all times.
